prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: UVISTA-Targets Spectral-Scan 1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
These observations are a spectral scan in Band 6 to detect multiple CO, C1, and H20 lines for 15 dusty galaxies at 1 < z < 3. The goal is to detect these lines at S/N > 5 at 150 km/s spectral resolution.
Band 6 is broad and requires 10 tunings to cover it all. This first science goal is the first 5 tunings, the next science goal is the next 5 tunings.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The likely linewidth of our targets is 200-400 km/s. We aim for a velocity resolution of 150 km/s, to attain a high signal-to-noise ratio in each line. We request FDM mode with 1875 MHz of bandwidth. We will use 16x frequency binning to reduce the data load. The will result in a velocity resolution of 20 km/s. The data will then be binned to coarser velocity resolution, based on the precise linewidth and noise ratio of the source.

Our targets have a likely angular size of 0.5 - 1.0 arcseconds. We therefore request a resolution of 1.0 arcsecond, as we do not need to resolve the sources. We do not require complementary ACA observations.

Our sensitivity estimate is driven by our goal of detecting a range of CO lines at 1 < z < 4. We have estimated the CO line flux densities as follows. We have estimated the L_IR and star formation rates (SFRs) for each galaxy based on their photometric redshifts and 24um fluxes. These span the range of 100 - 700 M_sun/yr. We have based the following calculation on a conservative SFR estimate of 100 M_sun/yr for each galaxy, which is the lower-limit of all sources.
From a SFR we estimate a total H2 gas mass by assuming a constant molecular gas conversion time of 2 Gyr. We then estimate a flux density of CO(1-0) bu assuming a CO/H2 conversion factor of 3.5, suitable for star-forming objects at high-z (Tacconi et al. 2013). We extrapolate flux densities in the higher-J CO lines by assuming a spectral line energy distribution (SLED) typical for dusty galaxies at z ~ 2 (Bothwell et al. 2013).
Our requested rms (1.1 mJy per 150 km/s channel) will be sufficient to detect the faintest CO line in Band 6 at this redshift - CO(4-3) - at a significance of 5 sigma. Higher order CO lines will be detected at higher significance, up to 8 sigma. We stress this is a very conservative estimate based on a SFR of only 100 M_sun/yr. If the SFRs of the galaxies are higher, up to 700 M_sun/yr, as implied by the L_IR, then all CO lines will be detected at much higher significance, as high as S/N = 30.
This rms has been calculated assuming a 150km/s channel. Being a redshift-scan, our aim is simply to detect each line. We therefore choose a channel width closely matched to the likely line width of our sources (200-400 km/s).
We are aware that the S/N over 1/3 of the line width is <3 in the chart above. However, the overal S/N will be 5 (for the faintest line) because our science goals do not require us to kinematically resolve the lines: we aim to detect the position of the lines, which is best achieved by matching the channel width to the expected line width.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: UVISTA-Targets Spectral-Scan 2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
These observations are a spectral scan in Band 6 to detect multiple CO, C1, and H20 lines for 15 dusty galaxies at 1 < z < 3. The goal is to detect these lines at S/N > 5 at 150 km/s spectral resolution.
Band 6 is broad and requires 10 tunings to cover it all. This first science goal is the first 5 tunings, this science goal is the next 5 tunings.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The likely linewidth of our targets is 200-400 km/s. We aim for a velocity resolution of 150 km/s, to attain a high signal-to-noise ratio in each line. We request FDM mode with 1875 MHz of bandwidth. We will use 16x frequency binning to reduce the data load. The will result in a velocity resolution of 20 km/s. The data will then be binned to coarser velocity resolution, based on the precise linewidth and noise ratio of the source.

Our targets have a likely angular size of 0.5 - 1.0 arcseconds. We therefore request a resolution of 1.0 arcsecond, as we do not need to resolve the sources. We do not require complementary ACA observations.

Our sensitivity estimate is driven by our goal of detecting a range of CO lines at 1 < z < 4. We have estimated the CO line flux densities as follows. We have estimated the L_IR and star formation rates (SFRs) for each galaxy based on their photometric redshifts and 24um fluxes. These span the range of 100 - 700 M_sun/yr. We have based the following calculation on a conservative SFR estimate of 100 M_sun/yr for each galaxy, which is the lower-limit of all sources.

We then estimate a flux density of CO(1-0) bu assuming a CO/H2 conversion factor of 3.5, suitable for star-forming objects at high-z (Tacconi et al. 2013). This rms has been calculated assuming a 150km/s channel. Being a redshift-scan, our aim is simply to detect each line. We therefore choose a channel width closely matched to the likely line width of our sources (200-400 km/s).

However, the overal S/N will be 5 (for the faintest line) because our science goals do not require us to kinematically resolve the lines: we aim to detect the position of the lines, which is best achieved by matching the channel width to the expected line width.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Using new ultra-deep near-infrared data from the UltraVISTA survey, we have uncovered a new population of massive galaxies at z ~ 2 that appear to have extraordinary dust obscuration of their stellar populations, Av = 3.0 - 5.0. This amount of obscuration is substantially more than seen in classical submillimeter galaxies, which typically have Av = 1.5 - 2.5. If truly this dusty, this population are undoubtedly the most dust-obscured galaxies in the universe. The largest uncertainty with these galaxies are their redshifts, as even with ultra-deep 38-band UV/IR/MIR photometric data, the lack of strong features in their SEDs leaves considerable uncertainty in the photometric redshift, and hence the total dust content. They are far too faint for conventional optical/NIR spectroscopy, so we request Band 6 spectral scans of a mass-complete sample of 15 of these galaxies. Our primary goal is to detect multiple CO transitions to pinpoint both their spectroscopic redshift and to measure approximate gas fractions. Once redshifts for this population are determined, this will open up an exciting opportunity to study the properties of the dustiest galaxies in the universe.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy, Cambridge, University of
